alert.note: Alert for Belknap; Grafton (New Hampshire) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Warning issued December 24 at 11:38AM EST until December 24 at 6:55PM EST by NWS Gray/Portland
info.description: ...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in New Hampshire and Maine... Pemigewasset River At Plymouth affecting Grafton and Belknap Counties. Kennebec River At Skowhegan affecting Somerset and Kennebec Counties. Suncook River At North Chichester affecting Merrimack and Belknap Counties. ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Maine... Kennebec River at Hallowell affecting Sagadahoc and Kennebec Counties. Kennebec River At Augusta affecting Kennebec County. ...The Flood Warning is cancelled for the following rivers in Maine and New Hampshire... Saco River At Conway affecting Carroll, Oxford, and Cumberland Counties. Piscataquog River NEAR Goffstown affecting Hillsborough County. Kennebec River At North Sidney affecting Kennebec County. Warner River At Davisville affecting Merrimack County. For the Kennebec River...including Skowhegan, North Sidney, Augusta, Hallowell...Minor flooding is forecast. For the Suncook River...including North Chichester...Minor flooding is forecast. ...FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL THIS EVENING... * WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring. * WHERE...Pemigewasset River at Plymouth. * WHEN...Until this evening. * IMPACTS...At 13.0 feet, Minor lowland flooding begins. At 14.0 feet, Water enters the parking lot behind the PSU ice arena. At 15.0 feet, Flood waters up to the road at the Irving station on route 175A in Holderness. At 15.5 feet, Flood waters over the road at the Irving station on route 175A in Holderness. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 10:46 AM EST Saturday the stage was 13.1 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 10:46 AM EST Saturday was 15.2 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall to 2.9 feet Tuesday morning. - Flood stage is 13.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 13.4 feet on 04/29/2008. &&
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov/gray.
